- "These aren’t administrative workflows. They’re clinical decisions, executed with speed, consistency, and scalability no human can match."
- "And not because they lack value, but because the reimbursement system doesn’t yet recognize intelligence as infrastructure."
- "A subtle change in definition. A massive shift in what becomes possible."
structuredSections.detailedContent:
- How can CMS evolve policy to meet the realities of modern healthcare delivery, particularly where digital infrastructure is no longer auxiliary, but foundational?
- There is one clear opportunity: Reimburse Distributed Clinical Logic.
- Across the system today, software (not people) is making real-time decisions that directly impact care, such as:
  - Routing a patient from surgery to physical therapy
  - Escalating behavioral risk based on pattern decompensation
  - Titrating medication timing based on dynamic context
  - Detecting social need and auto-triggering intervention
- These are clinical decisions, not administrative workflows, executed with speed, consistency, and scalability no human can match.
- Unfortunately, none of this is billable.
  - Not under Fee-For-Service (FFS).
  - Not under most Alternative Payment Models (APMs).
  - Not under most value-based tech carveouts.
- As a result, systems that think, coordinate, escalate, and guide care with clinical-grade intelligence are treated as cost centers.
- This is not because they lack value, but because the reimbursement system doesn’t yet recognize intelligence as infrastructure.
- I am proposing that it should.
- What is Distributed Clinical Logic (DCL)?
  - It’s a framework for understanding how real-time, rule-based or AI-enabled decision engines guide care delivery across the system.
  - It operates everywhere care happens, not in one place.
  - It acts as a persistent, embedded substrate of coordination, not through one person.
  - It is:
    - Deterministic when it needs to be
    - Probabilistic when it must be
    - Clinically governed always
  - It doesn’t replace clinicians; it frees them from what doesn’t require their expertise so they can focus on where it does.
  - It scales quality.
- Why Now?
  - This logic is already here, inside RPM dashboards, prior authorization platforms, population health tools, and care management engines.
  - However, none of it is incentivized the right way.
  - The opportunity cost of not acting is enormous.
- I believe CMS could lead the industry in reframing this layer not as “tech,” not as “admin,” but as billable, clinical infrastructure.
- This would be a subtle change in definition but would cause a massive shift in what becomes possible.
- I have a proposed framework for how this model could work, including use cases, reimbursement structures, stakeholder benefits, and implementation tiers.
- I welcome the opportunity to collaborate further.undefined

structuredSections.oneLineSummary: Two technology companies specializing in zero-trust AI security and clinical neurofeedback propose a joint platform for secure at-home care, outlining a detailed pilot program and recommending specific CMS actions to foster a secure, interoperable digital health ecosystem.
structuredSections.commenterProfile:
- **Name/Organization:** ZeroTrusted.ai LLC & Healix
- **Type:** Business
- **Role/Expertise:** ZeroTrusted.ai is a zero-trust AI security platform with federal and DoD clients. Its CEO, Waylon Krush, is a Service-Disabled Veteran with HHS cybersecurity leadership experience. Healix has a 25-year history in clinical neurofeedback solutions for PTSD, depression, and cognitive health.
- **Geographic Scope:** National
- **Stake in Issue:** As technology vendors, they are proposing their integrated platform as a solution for CMS's at-home care initiatives and have a direct commercial interest in the standards and policies CMS adopts.
structuredSections.corePosition: We are responding to CMS’s RFI to advance a patient-centered, secure, and interoperable at-home care platform. By integrating industry-leading zero-trust security, AI governance, and proven clinical neurofeedback, our joint solution will empower Medicare beneficiaries and their care teams. Together, we will help CMS realize its vision of a modern, patient-centered digital health ecosystem, unlocking innovation, strengthening security, and improving health outcomes for Medicare beneficiaries.
structuredSections.keyRecommendations:
- **Adopt a "Trust Mark" Certification:** Create a CMS-vetted badge for security, privacy, usability, and clinical efficacy of digital health applications, with ongoing AI-powered monitoring for compliance.
- **Provide Financial Incentives:**
  - Offer reimbursement add-ons for remote monitoring services like neurofeedback and continuous telemetry.
  - Offer shared-savings credits to providers for demonstrated reductions in hospital readmissions.
  - Tie payers' API certification readiness to Medical Loss Ratio (MLR) credit.
- **Enhance Data Access & Interoperability Standards:**
  - Extend the Blue Button 2.0 API to include device-generated FHIR Observations and real-time streaming capabilities.
  - Elevate Bulk FHIR and SMART on FHIR to mandatory ONC certification criteria.
  - Create a new ONC certification criterion specifically for the ingestion of FHIR Observations from external medical devices.
  - Extend the TEFCA data model to officially include FHIR Observations from at-home devices.
- **Reduce Provider and Payer Burden:**
  - Establish a single, CMS-hosted, searchable FHIR endpoint registry.
  - Allow CMS to compute quality metrics server-side using provider-submitted bulk data.
  - Permit a single Bulk FHIR data feed to be used for both payer quality programs and CMS reporting.
- **Strengthen Information Blocking Enforcement:**
  - Tighten the "health IT performance" exception to include specific FHIR API Service Level Agreement (SLA) requirements.
  - Create public dashboards to display non-compliance and implement graduated penalties.
- **Promote Secure AI Adoption:**
  - Provide CMS-managed platform services (MCP services) to facilitate secure AI Agent integration for approved partners.
  - Fund grant-based hackathons and prize challenges to stimulate innovation in at-home care technology.
structuredSections.mainConcerns:
- **Data Fragmentation:** Patient data is scattered across numerous, non-interoperable systems, including EHR portals, device-specific apps, and payer websites, requiring multiple logins.
- **Burdensome Workflows:** Current digital health tools often create workflow interruptions and heavy documentation burdens for providers, hindering adoption.
- **Inadequate Interoperability:** Providers face a landscape of heterogeneous, proprietary device APIs, and TEFCA's framework currently omits crucial at-home device data.
- **Missing Application Features:** Existing patient-facing tools lack critical features like dynamic, granular consent management for data sharing and predictive alerts for health risks.
- **Ineffective Information Blocking Rules:** Information blocking persists due to technical issues like API timeouts and failed queries, and current exceptions are too broad.
- **Lack of Certified Data Pathways:** There is no certified, standardized process within CEHRT for providers to ingest and use patient-generated data from external at-home devices.
- **Inconsistent Price Transparency:** Price transparency initiatives are undermined by inconsistent data formats (JSON schemas) and outdated fee schedules.
structuredSections.notableExperiences:
- **Proposed a Detailed Pilot Program:** They outlined a specific 18-month, $645k-$1.14M pilot to deploy their integrated platform in VA and Medicare Advantage networks, detailing phases, metrics (e.g., PTSD symptom reduction), and a complete budget.
- **Innovative Use of AI:** The proposal includes novel AI applications, such as an "AI Judge" to automatically structure unstructured clinical notes and an "AI Health Check" dashboard to continuously monitor applications for compliance with security, privacy, and ethical standards.
- **Novel Role for CMS:** They suggest that CMS should provide core infrastructure, such as "Managed Component/Platform (MCP)" services, to enable smaller entities to securely integrate and deploy vetted AI agents, positioning CMS as a technology enabler.
- **Specific Clinical Use Case:** The comment is grounded in a concrete application: combining a zero-trust security platform with a clinical-grade neurofeedback device (Healix) already used for PTSD and depression, making abstract policy goals tangible.
- **Veteran-Led Expertise:** The perspective is uniquely informed by the ZeroTrusted.ai CEO's background as a Service-Disabled Veteran and former HHS cybersecurity leader, lending credibility to their security and government-focused recommendations.
structuredSections.keyQuotations:
- "[Propose a] 'Trust Mark' Certification: CMS-vetted security, privacy, usability, clinical efficacy badge to include ongoing monitoring via AI with ZeroTrusted.ai’s AI Healthcheck and report any deviations, security, privacy, reliability, or AI ethics violations to CMS."
- "Solution: ZeroTrusted.ai’s AI Judge tags and structures free-text notes; DICOM proxy for imaging ingestion; Easier adopting of AI without breaking current and future regulatory and compliance requirements."
- "Recommendation: CMS-maintained FHIR endpoint registry, indexed by NPI and OAuth metadata, open to all payers, CMS powered AI Agents to monitor and enforce Zero Trust Architecture, security, and privacy compliance."
structuredSections.detailedContent:
- **Executive Summary**
  - ZeroTrusted.ai and Healix are responding to the RFI to advance a patient-centered, secure, and interoperable at-home care platform.
  - Their joint solution leverages zero-trust security, AI governance, and proven clinical neurofeedback.
  - **Key Features of the Proposed Solution:**
    - **Patient Empowerment:** Integrates clinical-grade Healix Neurofeedback with at-home monitoring, giving beneficiaries full control over data sharing from wearables, smart beds, and other devices via a unified portal.
    - **Secure Interoperability:** Built on a zero-trust platform with API access supporting HL7 FHIR and SMART standards, ensuring seamless data exchange with real-time PII/PHI detection and role-based access control.
    - **Reduced Administrative Burden:** Uses AI to provide care-plan recommendations, automated coding support, and streamlined consent management. Outcome metrics are automatically escalated to providers.
    - **Scalable Pilot:** Proposes an 18-month pilot in VA and Medicare Advantage networks using Healix Neurofeedback devices and ZeroTrusted.ai’s secure, FedRAMP-moderate cloud platform.
  - **Company Backgrounds:**
    - **ZeroTrusted.ai:** An award-winning U.S. zero-trust AI security platform trusted by Federal, DoD, and regulated commercial customers. Co-founder and CEO Waylon Krush is a Service-Disabled Veteran with HHS cybersecurity leadership experience.
    - **Healix:** A 25-year track record in translating clinical research into accessible home-care solutions for PTSD, depression, and cognitive support.

- **Current Solution Alignment with CMS Objectives**
  - **Drive Development & Adoption of Digital Health Applications:**
    - The platform has a modular architecture using HL7 FHIR and SMART on FHIR for "plug-and-play" integration of third-party tools, LLMs, and device SDKs.
    - The pilot use case involves Healix Neurofeedback in VA clinics to collect usability and clinical data.
  - **Strengthen Interoperability & Secure Data Access:**
    - Utilizes standards like FHIR R4, DICOM, OAuth 2.0, and TLS 1.3.
    - A dynamic AI Gateway enforces PII detection/anonymization, role-based access control (RBAC), and audit logging, supporting HIPAA, HITECH, and NIST SP 800-53.
  - **Identify Barriers to Seamless Information Exchange:**
    - Addresses the challenge of disparate proprietary device APIs by using an adapter layer to normalize telemetry into FHIR Observations.
    - A policy engine enforces HHS and CMS security controls, adaptable to emerging threats and AI-specific issues.
  - **Reduce Administrative Burden & Accelerate Value-Based Care:**
    - Automates workflows with AI-powered care plan recommendations, billing code suggestions, and consent management.
    - Focuses on outcomes with real-time alerts for vital signs and automated post-visit summary reports.

- **Platform Architecture & Protocols**
  - AI Runtime Protection: PII/PHI detection and anonymization, copyright/plagiarism checks.
  - AI Gateway: Central API hub with a FHIR proxy, monitoring for AI Agents, policy enforcement, and zero-trust routing.
  - Agents & CoPilots: Task-specific AI modules for device onboarding, anomaly detection, and patient engagement.
  - Data Stores: Encrypted FHIR data lake, Vector DB for semantic search, and RAG for clinical knowledge retrieval with metadata tagging to monitor PII/PHI.
  - Telehealth & Integration: Secure WebRTC for video visits and SMART on FHIR apps embedded in EHR portals.

- **Cybersecurity & Privacy Compliance**
  - Adheres to HIPAA/HITECH with end-to-end encryption, audit trails, and breach notification workflows.
  - Aligns with CMS/HHS Security & Privacy Program requirements, including identity proofing, risk assessments, and penetration testing.
  - Aligns with NIST 800-53 controls and FISMA moderate baseline, with a roadmap to FISMA High.
  - Ensures data sovereignty and patient consent via a user portal, dynamic access tokens, and a Zero Trust Architecture with AI Monitoring.

- **Pilot Experiments & Metrics**
  - **Phase 1 (0–2 months):** Feasibility & Proof of Concept to integrate BrainBit SDK and verify neurofeedback loop. Metrics: signal fidelity, latency (<50ms).
  - **Phase 2 (2–6 months):** MVP Development to build the mobile app, AI Gateway, and conduct pre-tests. Metrics: user retention, system uptime (99.9%).
  - **Phase 3 (6–12 months):** Pilot Trials to deploy in VA and autism clinics and collect outcome data. Metrics: PTSD symptom reduction (PCL-5), user satisfaction (>85%).
  - **Phase 4 (12–18 months):** Scale & Launch to mass-produce headsets and scale the HIPAA-hardened cloud. Metrics: reduction in readmissions, ROI.

- **Budget & Timeline**
  - Total 18-month cost range: $645K – $1.14M, with a goal of 50–100% grant funding.
  - Timeline: Start July 2025, Complete December 2026.
  - **Cost Breakdown:**
    - Hardware R&D & Certification: $200K–$350K
    - Software Development & AI Integration: $250K–$400K
    - Platform Infrastructure (Cloud): $50K–$100K
    - Regulatory & Quality Assurance: $75K–$150K
    - Operations & Contingency: $70K–$140K

- **Best Practices for Adoption**
  - Engage patients, caregivers, and clinicians early through co-design workshops.
  - Use a phased rollout, starting with in-office supervised deployments before moving to home onboarding.
  - Provide role-based training and establish an AI ethics oversight committee.
  - Use AI Health Check dashboards for continuous improvement of algorithms and protocols.

- **A. Patients & Caregivers**
  - **PC-1. Health management apps:**
    - Top capabilities include a unified portal for neurofeedback metrics and other device data, an AI "Care Coach" for reminders, and secure care team collaboration tools.
  - **PC-2. Single-pane data access:**
    - Current gap is multiple logins. The solution is a zero-trust platform with a FHIR-based dashboard aggregating all health data under one sign-on.
  - **PC-3/PC-4. Useful & missing features:**
    - Existing strengths include Blue Button 2.0.
    - Missing features include a dynamic consent manager, predictive risk alerts, and a marketplace for vetted at-home therapies.
  - **PC-5. CMS’s role in encouraging adoption:**
    - "Trust Mark" Certification for vetted apps with ongoing AI monitoring.
    - Reimbursement incentives for remote monitoring.
    - Data-access enhancements like real-time streaming APIs and expanding Blue Button.
  - **PC-6. Accessibility & ease-of-use:**
    - Design should include large targets, voice UI, and multilingual support.
    - Onboarding should be simple, with zero-touch pairing and technician support for low-tech users.
  - **PC-7. Real-world data collection:**
    - Approach is an opt-in outcomes registry using Bulk FHIR to capture clinical, cost, and compliance metrics.

- **B. Providers**
  - **PR-1. Encouraging digital adoption:**
    - Obstacles are workflow interruptions and documentation burdens.
    - CMS can help by embedding SMART on FHIR apps in EHRs, offering shared-savings credits, and publishing clear guidance.
  - **PR-2. Workflow obstacles & mitigation:**
    - Challenges include varied device SDKs and manual charge capture.
    - Mitigation includes a unified device adapter and AI-driven documentation and billing suggestions.
  - **PR-3. Access to all EHR data formats:**
    - Solution uses an "AI Judge" to structure free-text and a DICOM proxy for imaging.
  - **PR-4. Third-party app access to administrative workflows:**
    - Recommends expanding FHIR scheduling profiles.
  - **PR-5. FHIR API support:**
    - They fully support a comprehensive list of FHIR APIs, including Patient Access, Provider Directory, Bulk FHIR, CDS Hooks, and others.
  - **PR-6. TEFCA’s role:**
    - Suggests broadening TEFCA's scope to include FHIR Observations from at-home devices.
  - **PR-7. Reducing provider burden:**
    - Recommends CMS compute quality metrics server-side from provider-submitted bulk data.
  - **PR-9/PR-10. Digital identity:**
    - Encourage integration of Login.gov/ID.me, with scoped OAuth consents to balance privacy and SSO.
  - **PR-12/PR-14. Information blocking:**
    - Revise exceptions to require FHIR SLAs, create public non-compliance dashboards, and simplify complaint submission.

- **C. Payers**
  - **PA-1. TEFCA limitations:**
    - Issues are uneven participation and omission of device data.
    - Suggests subsidizing QHIN onboarding and extending the TEFCA data model.
  - **PA-2. Accelerate API implementation:**
    - Incentivize payers by tying API certification to MLR credit and publishing performance scorecards.
  - **PA-3/PA-4. Digital identity & provider directory:**
    - Recommends a CMS-maintained FHIR endpoint registry monitored by CMS-powered AI agents.
  - **PA-5. Simplify clinical quality data:**
    - Permit Bulk FHIR feeds to serve both payer and CMS reporting; share toolkits for data transformation.
  - **PA-7. Payer information-blocking complaints:**
    - Embed a complaint form in payer portals and levy annual non-compliance fees.

- **D. Technology Vendors, Data Providers & Networks**
  - **TD-1. Stimulating developer interest:**
    - Suggests open-sourcing SDKs and hosting CMS/ONC-funded hackathons.
  - **TD-2. Valuable CMS data & new APIs:**
    - Desires additions like claims adjudication status, SDOH indices, and device-generated data.
    - Suggests CMS publish interactive API consoles and provide services for secure AI agent integration.
  - **TD-3. Digital identity:**
    - Mandate OpenID Connect for all FHIR APIs.
  - **TD-4/TD-5. Open standards & directory:**
    - Encourage FHIR R4 and phase out legacy APIs.
    - Recommends a CMS-hosted, searchable FHIR endpoint registry.
  - **TD-6/TD-7. TEFCA & USCDI:**
    - USCDI is missing device telemetry; propose a USCDI v4 extension for Observations and AI Agent integration.
  - **TD-8/TD-11. Certification criteria:**
    - Elevate Bulk FHIR and SMART on FHIR to mandatory ONC criteria.
  - **TD-12/TD-13. Non-CMS data sources:**
    - Permit inclusion of vendor-generated Observations in Blue Button 2.0 extensions.
  - **TD-14/TD-17. FHIR networks & bulk APIs:**
    - Recommend daily delta feeds for Bulk FHIR to address staleness.
  - **TD-18. Information blocking:**
    - Address with API-specific performance SLAs and public disclosures.
  - **TD-19. Price transparency:**
    - Mandate a standard schema and embed cost estimates in scheduling apps.

- **E. Value-Based Care Organizations**
  - **VB-1. Incentives for ACOs/APMs:**
    - Offer shared savings for reduced ED visits and quality bonuses for validated mental-health improvements.
  - **VB-2. Integrating AI & analytics:**
    - Use AI for population risk stratification and proactive care-plan interventions.
  - **VB-3. Essential IT capabilities:**
    - Require event notifications for vitals excursions and dashboards that fuse claims and device data.
  - **VB-5/VB-6. CEHRT & ONC certification:**
    - The gap is a lack of certified ingestion for external device data.
    - Recommend a new ONC criterion for FHIR Observations from medical devices.
  - **VB-7-VB-10. Streamlining APM requirements:**
    - Allow modular certification for providers.
    - Extend event notification requirements to APM participants.
    - Create a single nationwide directory for FHIR endpoints.

- **Why ZeroTrusted.ai & Healix?**
  - Proven security and compliance with Federal, DoD, and regulated organizations.
  - 25 years of clinical neurofeedback expertise.
  - Leadership by a Service-Disabled Veteran with HHS cybersecurity experience.
  - Experience securing grants and a roadmap to FedRAMP High.
  - An outcome-driven platform prioritizing clinical efficacy, patient experience, and cost-savings.

structuredSections.oneLineSummary: An individual with home health expertise argues that before promoting digital health, CMS must address the rural technology gap and drastically simplify the "redundant and excessive" OASIS documentation burden on providers.
structuredSections.commenterProfile:
- **Name/Organization:** Susan Crandall
- **Type:** Individual
- **Role/Expertise:** Implicitly a Home Health professional, based on detailed comments on the OASIS assessment process.
- **Geographic Scope:** Local/State (OR) with a focus on rural areas.
- **Stake in Issue:** Directly impacted by the administrative burden of OASIS documentation and the practical challenges of providing care to patients with limited technology access.
structuredSections.corePosition: Before encouraging digital health products, CMS must recognize that many people in rural areas lack access to PCs or even cell coverage. Home health should be empowered to provide timely, quality skilled visits to these patients by reducing the massive amount of paperwork currently required in the OASIS documentation. The current assessment is redundant, excessive, and not meaningful for sharing with other providers.
structuredSections.keyRecommendations:
- Drastically reduce the administrative burden of the Home Health OASIS assessment.
  - The assessment should be simplified to include only meaningful data that is descriptive of the patient's condition, eliminating duplication.
  - The current 110-question form is excessive, with only a few questions being truly useful.
- Empower home health agencies to conduct more skilled visits for patients in rural areas who lack technology access, enabled by reduced paperwork.
structuredSections.mainConcerns:
- A significant digital divide prevents the adoption of digital health tools in rural areas, where many patients lack PCs or reliable cell phone coverage.
- Lack of interoperability between different provider EHR systems hinders access to complete patient medical histories, compromising continuity of care.
- The current OASIS assessment is too burdensome and not clinically useful for data sharing.
  - Sharing the full, unedited assessment would overwhelm physicians with redundant, non-meaningful information.
- Increased data exchange and interoperability create the potential for HIPAA violations if patient consent is not properly managed.
structuredSections.notableExperiences:
- The commenter provides a practitioner's perspective on the OASIS comprehensive assessment, labeling it "redundant and excessive."
- A key insight is that simply making the current OASIS data interoperable would be counterproductive, as it would overload physicians with useless information rather than improving care.
- The specific critique that out of 110 questions on the OASIS form, "only a handful... are truly descriptive of the patient’s condition or situation" highlights the scale of the perceived administrative waste.
structuredSections.keyQuotations:
- "The current assessment [OASIS] is redundant and excessive."
- "For Home Health, the comprehensive assessment (OASIS) needs to become more meaningful first – sharing the current assessment with the patient’s provider would be overload and not appreciated by the physician or approved provider."
- "Currently, there are 110 questions and only a handful of those questions are truly descriptive of the patient’s condition or situation."
structuredSections.detailedContent:
- REQUEST FOR INFORMATION: HEALTH TECHNOLOGY ECOSYSTEM
  - 1. Digital Health Apps
    - PR-1. What can CMS do to encourage providers to leverage approved digital health products, especially in rural areas?
      - Many people in rural areas lack access to PCs, and many do not even have cell coverage or use cell phones.
      - Home health should be empowered to make skilled visits to these patients.
      - This can be done by reducing the amount of paperwork CMS currently requires in the OASIS documentation, which would empower providers to deliver timely and quality care.
      - a. What are the current obstacles?
        - Lack of technology in the patient's home or surrounding area.
    - PR-3. How important is it for all data in an EHR system to be accessible for exchange?
      - a. Current challenges in accessing different data formats.
        - Providers use different EHRs that do not interface with one another.
        - For example, we have limited or no access to some of the hospital/health care systems that provide us with referrals.
      - b. Impact on patient care quality.
        - The patient's medical history is not accessible.
        - Continuity of care is compromised.
      - d. Cost or privacy implications of making all data formats interoperable.
        - There is a potential for a HIPAA violation if a patient has not given consent.
  - 2. Data Exchange
    - PR-7. What strategies can CMS implement to support providers in making data available for interoperability?
      - For Home Health, the comprehensive assessment (OASIS) must first become more meaningful.
      - Sharing the current assessment with a patient’s provider would be an overload and would not be appreciated by the physician.
      - The current assessment is redundant and excessive.
    - PR-8. What are ways CMS can help simplify clinical quality data responsibilities?
      - For Home Health, reduce the OASIS assessment to only meaningful data without duplication.
      - The current assessment has 110 questions, but only a handful are truly descriptive of the patient’s condition or situation.
      - b. In what ways can the interoperability and quality reporting responsibilities of providers be consolidated?
        - [No response provided]

structuredSections.oneLineSummary: A cardiologist with 50 years of experience proposes that Medicare offer seniors a free, vetted lifestyle coaching app to improve chronic disease management and simultaneously build an invaluable biometric data bank.
structuredSections.commenterProfile:
- **Name/Organization:** Metacardio
- **Type:** Healthcare Provider
- **Role/Expertise:** US-licensed cardiologist with 50 years of clinical experience and over 30 years in digital health; developer of the "Metacardio Healing Habits" mobile app.
- **Geographic Scope:** National
- **Stake in Issue:** As a physician and digital health developer, he proposes a solution to improve preventative care for seniors on a national scale using technology he has developed.
structuredSections.corePosition: I suggest that your quest for an interoperable infrastructure be a value-added proposition for all stakeholders. A healthy lifestyle is the bedrock for managing chronic conditions, but it is sparsely adopted by patients and poorly taught by providers. A ready solution is for Medicare to offer all seniors a credible and effective lifestyle coaching mobile app as a free download.
structuredSections.keyRecommendations:
- Medicare should offer a free, vetted, and effective lifestyle coaching mobile app to all seniors.
  - The app should provide daily, science-based, and engaging prompts, nudges, and micro-steps to encourage healthy habits.
- Medicare should contract with vetted healthcare entities that offer such mobile apps.
  - A condition of the contract should be that the app securely transmits patient health information (e.g., biometrics) to a central Medicare data bank.
- The commenter offers his own "Metacardio Healing Habits" app to Medicare for this purpose.
  - He offers the app without any fees.
  - He states the app could be modified with minor effort to become an interoperable personal health record tracker.
structuredSections.mainConcerns:
- Healthy lifestyles are critical for managing nearly every serious chronic medical condition, yet this approach is underutilized.
- Patients are not widely adopting healthy lifestyles.
- Healthcare providers are not effectively teaching patients how to live a healthy lifestyle.
- The current model of sporadic clinic visits is inherently incapable of achieving sustained, daily lifestyle changes.
structuredSections.notableExperiences:
- The proposal cleverly links a consumer-facing wellness initiative (a free app for seniors) directly to the goal of building a national, interoperable health data infrastructure.
- The commenter, a retiring cardiologist, makes the highly unusual offer to provide his own fully developed mobile application ("Metacardio Healing Habits") to Medicare entirely for free, stating his only motive is to be of service.
- He provides a compelling contrast between the failure of "sporadic clinic visits" and the potential success of "daily, sensible, delightful" digital nudges for promoting lasting behavior change.
structuredSections.keyQuotations:
- "A healthy lifestyle is recognized as the bedrock for managing almost every serious chronic medical condition. Yet, it is sparsely adopted by patients and poorly taught by providers."
- "Daily, sensible, delightful, updated, science-based prompts, nudges, microsteps, and information nuggets will do what sporadic clinic visits can never achieve."
- "I will not charge Medicare any fees. I only want to be of service as a retiring medical professional."
structuredSections.detailedContent:
- The quest for an interoperable infrastructure should be a value-added proposition for all stakeholders.
- A healthy lifestyle is the foundation for managing almost every serious chronic medical condition.
  - However, it is sparsely adopted by patients and poorly taught by providers.
- There is a ready solution that would also serve the goal of building a data infrastructure.
  - Almost every senior uses a smartphone.
  - Medicare should offer all seniors a credible and effective lifestyle coaching mobile app as a free download.
  - Daily, sensible, delightful, and science-based prompts, nudges, and information can achieve what sporadic clinic visits cannot.
  - Both seniors and providers would welcome this because they know it is needed.
- Medicare can contract with vetted healthcare entities offering such an app.
  - A condition would be that the patients’ health information is transmitted to a Medicare data bank.
- With confidentiality ensured by Medicare, the app could track seniors’ biometrics.
  - Examples include weight, blood pressure, pulse rate, exercise times, and sleep patterns.
  - This bio-information bank would be invaluable for Medicare’s public health purposes and healthcare system planning.
- An example of such an application is the “Metacardio Healing Habits” app, which is already in use.
- The commenter welcomes Medicare or its designated entities to adopt his Metacardio app.
  - With minor modifications, this iOS app can become an interoperable personal health record tracker.
- The commenter will not charge Medicare any fees.
  - He states his only desire is to be of service as a retiring medical professional.
- More information is available at his non-monetized website, www.metacardio.org.

structuredSections.oneLineSummary: An Iowa consumer advises the government to implement new technology like AI slowly, emphasizing the need for patient testing, user education, and providing factual information to build public trust.
structuredSections.commenterProfile:
- **Name/Organization:** Roger Lacoy
- **Type:** Individual
- **Role/Expertise:** Not specified; writes from a consumer/patient perspective.
- **Geographic Scope:** Local/State (IA)
- **Stake in Issue:** As a potential user of healthcare services, he will be affected by the implementation of new technologies.
structuredSections.corePosition: I believe new technologies like AI must be introduced slowly and cautiously into healthcare services. To overcome significant public trust issues with technology and the government, it is essential that all new methods are patient-tested and that users are provided with factual information and proper training.
structuredSections.keyRecommendations:
- Implement new technology, particularly AI, slowly.
- Ensure all new methods are patient-tested by appropriate age ranges.
- Provide education and training on the new technology to the people using the services.
- Distribute factual information to help the public differentiate real information from misinformation and build trust.
structuredSections.mainConcerns:
- There are significant public trust issues with new technology, new methodologies, and the government.
- Without proper education, people may not be able to use new technological services effectively.
- The public finds it difficult to determine what information is real and who to believe.
structuredSections.notableExperiences: No distinctive experiences shared.
structuredSections.keyQuotations:
- "Go slow, there are alot of trust issues with new technology, methodology and the government itself."
- "It's hard to tell what's real these days or who to believe so provide factual information."
structuredSections.detailedContent:
- Whatever methods are used must be patient-tested by the appropriate age ranges.
- The use of AI should be incorporated slowly.
- Technology has to be taught to the people who will be using the services.
- It is important to proceed slowly, as there are many trust issues with new technology, new methodology, and the government itself.
- Factual information should be provided, as it is hard for people to tell what is real or who to believe in the current environment.undefined

structuredSections.oneLineSummary: A healthcare industry professional demands ironclad privacy controls and hack-proof security for digital health records, insisting on explicit patient consent for any data sharing and an end to legal loopholes.
structuredSections.commenterProfile:
- **Name/Organization:** mike adams
- **Type:** Healthcare Provider
- **Role/Expertise:** Not specified
- **Geographic Scope:** Local/State (California)
- **Stake in Issue:** As a professional in the healthcare industry and an individual, they are directly affected by data security standards and privacy rules for digital health information.
structuredSections.corePosition: I am sick of being forced by companies to use digital systems only to learn they have been hacked and our data is exposed. The people's health identifiable information should and must stay private. Under no circumstance should it be shared with any party without the explicit consent of the individual, and individuals must be able to audit who has accessed their information.
structuredSections.keyRecommendations:
- Scrutinize and harden all health technology to a standard that makes hacking "almost impossible."
- Require explicit, individual patient consent before any health information is shared with any third party.
- Grant individuals the right to audit who has accessed their personal health information.
- Strictly apply the "ethos of least privilege" to all health data disclosures, ensuring only the minimum necessary information is shared.
- Eliminate "lawyer language" and loopholes from privacy regulations to make them simple, clear, and not open to interpretation.
- Specifically, amend the exceptions to disclosure in laws like the 1974 Privacy Act.
- Consider using systems like MyChart as a base model for user-friendly design and functionality.
structuredSections.mainConcerns:
- Vague definitions in regulations allow for health data to be shared with third parties without patient consent.
- Digital health technology is not secure enough, leading to frequent data breaches that expose personal information.
- The current remedies for data breaches, such as offering a free credit report via a physical letter, are inadequate and ironic.
- Legal loopholes, particularly the "routine use" and other exceptions in the 1974 Privacy Act, critically undermine privacy protections.
- There is a risk of inappropriate data sharing between healthcare providers and unrelated third parties, such as financial companies (Visa) or credit bureaus (Experian/TransUnion).
- Individuals lack control over their own health data and cannot track who has accessed it.
structuredSections.notableExperiences:
- Highlights the irony of the digital-first push by noting that notifications for digital data breaches are often sent via a physical letter in the mail.
- Proposes a clear, actionable principle from the tech world—the "ethos of least privilege"—as the guiding standard for all health data sharing.
- Provides a specific, compelling example of potential overreach: a doctor's office sharing co-pay information (paid with a Visa card) with Visa or a credit bureau.
- Cites the 1974 Privacy Act and its disclosure exceptions as a specific legal area that must be reformed, showing a more detailed understanding of the policy landscape.
structuredSections.keyQuotations:
- "I am so sick of being forced by companies to go digital only to hear they have been hacked and your data is potentially out in the open."
- "For the rights of Americans I urge whomever concerned in developing this to have a backbone and really stop the lawyer language and loopholes."
- "It's actually very simple just follow the ethos of least privilege."
structuredSections.detailedContent:
- One of the biggest issues with the shift to digital health and interoperability is loose definitions.
- These loose definitions allow all parties to share data with others, including third-party entities, often without consent.
- Technology must be scrutinized and hardened to a point where it passes a test making hacking almost impossible.
- I am sick of being forced by companies to go digital only to hear they have been hacked and my data is potentially out in the open.
  - In response to a breach, individuals often just get a free credit report.
  - The notification for this is usually sent as a physical letter in the mail, which is ironic.
- For the rights of Americans, I urge developers of this regulation to have a backbone and stop the "lawyer language" and loopholes.
- People's personally identifiable health information should and must stay private.
- It should not be shared with any party under any circumstance without the individual's consent.
- The individual must also be able to audit who has accessed their information.
- For example, if a patient uses their Visa ATM card for a co-pay, the doctor's office should not share anything with Visa, Experian, TransUnion, or anyone else.
- Another example: if records are needed for a specialty doctor, only the specialist should be provided the information, and only after the patient has authorized the disclosure.
- The guiding principle is simple: follow the ethos of least privilege.
- The section of law governing disclosures must be cleaned up, simplified, and not left open for interpretation.
  - The 1974 Privacy Act section on disclosures to third parties is an example.
  - Of the twelve exceptions, the most significant are "need to know," disclosures required by FOIA, and the "routine use" exception.
  - Link provided: https://www.justice.gov/opcl/overview-privacy-act-1974-2020-edition/disclosures-third-parties
- MyChart has a very user-friendly front end and allows primary care doctors to review referrals and prescriptions.
- It could serve as a nice base for a system model.

structuredSections.oneLineSummary: A healthcare industry professional from Missouri proposes creating a single, mandatory national database of personal health information to solve the systemic complexity and cost caused by disparate data.
structuredSections.commenterProfile:
- **Name/Organization:** Paul Helmering
- **Type:** Healthcare Provider
- **Role/Expertise:** [Not specified, but implies expertise in healthcare data and systems architecture]
- **Geographic Scope:** National (commenting from Missouri)
- **Stake in Issue:** As a healthcare industry professional, is impacted by the complexity and cost of a system with fragmented data.
structuredSections.corePosition: I believe the entire US healthcare system is built on a foundation of sand because the data are disparate. This fragmentation plagues every national initiative and operational process with extreme complexity and cost. To effectively manage the health of the US population and the system's complexities, I believe we need to centralize the data into a single national database of personal health information.
structuredSections.keyRecommendations:
- Create a single, centralized national database for all personal health information.
- Mandate that all commercial EHRs and other healthcare applications must utilize and leverage this central database.
structuredSections.mainConcerns:
- The current system of disparate data creates a flawed foundation for the entire US healthcare system.
- This fragmentation leads to extreme complexity and high costs for all national initiatives and operational processes.
- Any effort to improve healthcare will be hampered until this foundational data architecture problem is solved.
structuredSections.notableExperiences:
- The comment uses the powerful metaphor of the US healthcare system being "built on a foundation of sand" to describe the core problem of disparate data.
- Proposes a single, radical solution—a mandatory national health database—to a systemic problem, acknowledging the profound challenge but emphasizing the even greater potential results.
structuredSections.keyQuotations:
- "I believe the entire US healthcare system is built on a foundation of sand because the data are disparate."
- "To effectively manage the health of the US population and the complexities of the US healthcare system I believe we need to centralize the data -- a single national database of personal health information that all commercial EHRs and applications would be required to utilize and leverage."
structuredSections.detailedContent:
- The entire US healthcare system is built on a flawed foundation because its data is disparate.
- Every national initiative and operational process is and will continue to be plagued with extreme complexity and cost due to this architecture.
- To effectively manage the health of the US population and the system's complexities, the data must be centralized.
  - The proposed solution is a single national database of personal health information.
  - All commercial EHRs and applications would be required to use and leverage this database.
- This is a profound national challenge, but the results would be even more profound.
- The commenter offers to provide additional information or assistance with such a project.
